average_years_schooling.long_description: The Education Index measures the average education level achieved by the adult population in an area. This is based on the average years of schooling in an area. The calculation used to calculate the index can be found in (Bennett, D.L. Educational Inequailty in the United States: Methodology and Historical Estimates of Education Gini Coefficients. Econ. Modeling Microeconom. Stud. Health 2001). Higher educational attainment has been shown to have positive impacts on economic earning and positive health outcomes.

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

dent_e2sfca.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). earnings_per_job.long_description:
Earnings per job is calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table from the Bureau of Economic Analysis. Raw data observations are generally per county/city; however, some observations involve multiple counties/cities. For example, Fairfax County, Fairfax City and Falls Church City are grouped into one observation in the raw data.  We split the multi-county/city raw data observations into multiple observations so that one observation corresponds to only one county/city.  We set the value of each split individual observation to be that of the corresponding raw multi-county/city observation.

These are the multi-county/city groupings in the raw data: Albemarle County, Charlottesville; Alleghany County, Covington; Augusta County, Staunton, Waynesboro; Campbell County,  Lynchburg; Carroll County, Galax; Dinwiddie County, Colonial Heights, Petersburg; Fairfax County, Fairfax City, Falls Church; Frederick County, Winchester; Greensville County, Emporia; Henry County,  Martinsville; James City County, Williamsburg; Montgomery County, Radford; Pittsylvania County, Danville; Prince George County, Hopewell; Prince William County, Manassas, Manassas Park; Roanoke County, Salem; Rockbridge County, Buena Vista, Lexington; Rockingham County, Harrisonburg; Southampton County, Franklin; Spotsylvania County, Fredericksburg; Washington County, Bristol; Wise County, Norton; York County, Poquoson.

gini_index.long_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality. The Gini coefficient incorporates the detailed shares data into a single statistic, which summarizes the dispersion of income across the entire income distribution. The Gini coefficient ranges from 0, indicating perfect equality (where everyone receives an equal share), to 1, perfect inequality (where only one recipient or group of recipients receives all the income). The Gini is based on the difference between the Lorenz curve (the observed cumulative income distribution) and the notion of a perfectly equal income distribution.

insecure_pc_original.long_description: Proportion of households facing food insecurity, based on a financial model considering income category and household size. The food security status is determined after comparing household income versus cost-of-living. Cost of living includes eight categories, including food, housing, healthcare, childcare, transportation, taxes, internet, and other expenses.
insecure_pc_original.long_name: Estimated percentage of total households facing food insecurity
insecure_pc_original.short_description: Proportion of households facing food insecurity, based on a financial model considering income category and household size.
insecure_pc_original.short_name: Food Insecure Households Percent (Unsubsidized, UVA alpha ver.)

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Department   of Labor Women’s Bureau National
National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

insecure_pc_snap.long_description: Proportion of households facing food insecurity after receiving an estimated amount of SNAP benefits, considering income category and household size. Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). 2year.long_description: Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates

under2year.long_description: certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years

schools_2year_{category.name}.short_description: Number of 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_{category.name}.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates{category} per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_{category.name}.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.
